Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2014
Award.AbstractNarration:
NSF Postdoctoral Fellowships in Biology combine research and training components to prepare young scientists for careers in emerging areas where biology intersects with other scientific disciplines, in this case with mathematics and physical sciences. The Fellows are expected to be leaders of the nation's scientific workforce of the future. This fellowship to Dr. Rodrigo Olarte supports a research and training plan to understand genetic elements, called cryptic alleles, in the fungus Aspergillus flavus which can contaminate foods by producing aflatoxins. Research results are expected to be useful in formulating better control strategies that target the reduction or elimination of aflatoxin contamination in agriculturally important crops susceptible to A. flavus infection such as corn, cotton and peanut. The host institution for this fellowship is the University of Minnesota and the sponsoring scientists are Drs. Georgiana May and Yaniv Brandvain. The Fellow?s training goals include learning mathematical modeling techniques and applying ecological experimentation to determine the origin, composition and distribution of the cryptic alleles in a global context. Educational outreach activities include training and mentoring undergraduates in programs, such as the Undergraduate Research Opportunities Program.

Fungi produce a wealth of metabolic compounds but little is known of the evolutionary origin or ecological importance of these diverse compounds. In this research, aflatoxin production by A. flavus is being used as a model system to investigate the ecological factors affecting the evolution of microbial toxins. Cryptic alleles are suggested to have arisen early in the evolution of the species and since been maintained in A. flavus populations for long periods of time. This research aims to understand the functional significance of these cryptic alleles as they pertain to the competiveness of isolates expressing quantitative and qualitative variation in mycotoxin production. The overall goal of this project is to gain a better understanding of how ecological and evolutionary processes affect variation at the aflatoxin gene cluster and population-level variation in A. flavus.

POR.DRECONTENT:
My project was to characterize and evaluate cryptic alleles found in the fungal pathogen Aspergillus flavus.  Previously, cryptic alleles were discovered in experimental crosses between A. flavus strains of opposite mating type.  Cryptic alleles are a phenomenon that have been reported in other organisms including Arabidopsis and Saccharomyces, both of which are model organisms; cryptic alleles are extrachromosomal elements that are present in less than single copy number per genome.  When found in A. flavus, I thought this system would be great for studying cryptic alleles because large genomic deletions or aneuploidies are a natural occurrence in this organism, which should allow for detection and tracing back to their originating parental isolate.  After multiple attempts at finding the cryptic alleles using various bioinformatics tools including different de novo assembly tools such as Velvet, SGA, SPAdes and Abyss; as well as implementation of the Genome Alignment Toolkit, Mauve and BLAST for data analysis, we have not been able to find and recover any cryptic alleles.  We attribute this to the low copy number characteristic of these alleles and other sequencing platforms, e.g., PacBio long read sequencing, may be required for further study. 

Despite being unable to find cryptic alleles, which was the main focus of this project, I have received lots of training in bioinformatics and attended several workshops for professional development.  The workshops that I have attended include:  job submission and scheduling, data storage systems and data analysis workflows for research, quality control of illumine data with Galaxy, interactive computing, basics of RNA-Seq data analysis, digital gene expression analysis using Galaxy, quality control of Illumina data at the command line, PacBio sequencing, analysis of PacBio sequencing data using SMRT portal, python for scientific computing, creating discussions that work, efficient grading strategies, and course design for different learning spaces.  These workshops are not only very beneficial in preparing me for my future career as an academic professor, but also in strengthening my skills as a bioinformatician. 

In addition to my continued training in bioinformatics and professional development, I have also attended a workshop that focused on building proficiency in climate change education and research.  This workshop that included an afternoon seminar as well as a half-day professional development period, was attended by faculty, graduate students and postdocs, focused on developing a set of cultural proficiency tools that help examine, communicate and grow their ability to engage and mentor diverse learners – especially those from under-represented and under-served communities.   This workshop helped me understand effective ways of 1) recruiting and retaining diverse peers, 2) teaching and mentoring diverse students, and 3) doing science with students and colleagues from under-served and under-represented communities.  I remain in touch with several participants from this workshop and we plan to continue sharing further advancements in our own training with each other, and I plan to attend any related workshops on this topic in the future.

I organized a workshop at a gradate student retreat where I shared with new graduate students my experiences in obtaining a USDA-NIFA graduate fellowship and an NSF post-doctoral fellowship grant.  Another opportunity for outreach was a Field day event that happened in the summer of 2016 at the Waseca MN Southern Research and Outreach Center.  During this event, professors and other academic liasons worked with local growers and the public to educate them on best practices for agriculture and biocontrol usage.  I shared my knowledge of Aspergillus and aflatoxin to many growers in the area who were interested in minimizing any risks of this pathogen on their crops and livestock.

Finally, I was able to attend the Fungal Genetics conference in Pacific Grove CA, where I was able to discuss my project with fellow scientists and receive feedback for my methods and analyses.  I also presented my work at the Minnesota Supercomputing Institute Research Exhibition at the University of Minnesota, where I was able to present my project and again receive any feedback for continued data analysis using alternative methods for cryptic allele detection.

This fellowship has helped prepare me for a career in academia and has also enabled me to become more proficient with using bioinformatics as a tool in my research.
